physical_examinations.relevant_findings: Patients presented with dyspnea and hypoxia. CT scans revealed bilateral ground-glass opacities in two patients, and unilateral pulmonary consolidations in others.
physical_examinations.changes_over_time: Patient II-1 from family 1 experienced progressive respiratory insufficiency requiring intubation; he was later extubated and showed significant respiratory improvement. However, he later developed a left-sided pneumothorax requiring chest drain insertion.

physical_examinations.relevant_findings: One patient did not survive due to refractory shock and a secondary bacterial infection.
physical_examinations.changes_over_time: Patient II-2 from family 1 was treated with inotropic agents but ultimately did not survive, highlighting the severity of his condition.

physical_examinations.relevant_findings: Recovery of the patient I-1 was noted with the removal of chest drain after stable improvements in pneumothorax.
physical_examinations.changes_over_time: Patient II-1 showed improvement over time, gradually recovering and eventually being discharged home for rehabilitation.
